continent.title: A ressource in profusion
continent.subtitle: If you lived in North America, turns out you’d have been more likely to have access to clean water...if you were wealthy, white and didn’t live in a rural area or a First Nations’s community.
continent.content: As North America was considered as one of the richest part of earth, the notion of a community without access to clean water seemed like something that would only exist in a far-off, undeveloped country in the eyes of the rest of the world.

continent.subtitle: Did you know that Canada was one of the largest per capita users of fresh water in the world ?
continent.content: Canada's water ressources represented about 7% of renewable water in the world. Yet thousands of individuals from Native communities did not have access to drinking water in Canada, sometimes for decades, due to defective processing plants or contaminated sources.

keydata.text: Country in the world offering the easiest access to clean water
Of the entire world’s renewable water resources were flowing in Canada’s water streams

continent.subtitle: The US inhabitants were very fond into water's different uses. But careless about water waste
continent.content: Individual american citizens used more water than anyone else on the planet. The average american would use up to 80-100 gallons of water per day, from cooking to cleaning to flushing the toilet. What a massive consumption !
